channel.title: How are those $600-700 laptops (toshiba)
channel.description: I was thinking of buying one of those $600-$700 laptops I've been seeing on sale at Best Buy (Toshiba's, usually). Will they play half life 2, bioshock, etc. games at a decent frame rate?

item.title: How are those $600-700 laptops (toshiba)
item.dc:creator: Marb
item.description:
I’ve got a Satellite L505D and am loving Win7 for the most part. Plays HL2, EP1, Minerva and SMOD fairly decent - not a screamer but at least better than my old P4 desktop for sure. Only issue is a bit of FPS drop in games using a lot of fog/smoke/clouds of blood and HDR. Was getting some weird issues with Synergy, but I was trying to host a server…

Read full topic

item.title: How are those $600-700 laptops (toshiba)
item.dc:creator: sersoft
item.description:
laptops skyrocketed in performance over the last couple of months, nowdays you can get a core i7 laptop with a decent graphics card for less than a thousand bucks.

item.title: How are those $600-700 laptops (toshiba)
item.dc:creator: topsquid
item.description:
ar487:

Why wouldn’t you just get a tower, for $600 you could get a decent quad core. IDK too much about laptops but I know they (usually) skimp you on the graphics cards for “mobile editions”.

Well, it’s 1 GB graphics card, 16 inch screen, really cool keyboard/kinda rubbery, so it will keep me happy for 2-3 years.

Read full topic

item.title: How are those $600-700 laptops (toshiba)
item.dc:creator: topsquid
item.description:
Well…here it is dudes…

I BOUGHT AN ASUS LAPTOP W/ 1 GB NVIDIA GTX 260M VIDEO CARD. Model: G60VX-RBBX05…It plays codmw2 like a dream…god that “no russian” level was disturbing…but I digress.

teh bad news… It cost $899

Thanks for all your advice guys and happy fragging!

item.title: How are those $600-700 laptops (toshiba)
item.dc:creator: sersoft
item.description:
Yours is way too recent, maybe in a few months you’ll start seeing the problems.

My HP pavilion is a year and a half older than your Acer (1.88Ghz Core 2 Duo + 8400M GT) and it still works fine apart from battery life.

Read full topic

item.title: How are those $600-700 laptops (toshiba)
item.dc:creator: Naked_Shooter
item.description:
I’ve heard about people’s issues with Acer, but I have one and it’s been great so far. I carry it around everywhere, mash it in my bag, still works fine. Ran every game I threw at it, short of ARMA II. Played CS, Dragon Age: Origins and CoD4 just fine.

It’s an Aspire 6930G, got it on newegg for about $700

Core 2 duo p8600 (2.4Ghz)
4gigs of ddr2 ram
9600M GS nvidia graphics card
16’’ screen…

Read full topic

item.title: How are those $600-700 laptops (toshiba)
item.dc:creator: sersoft
item.description:
Toshiba is not bad, it ranks higher than Acer and HP in my book.

I’ve seen 4 acer laptops break beyond repair within 1 year, and most people already know about the overheating issues with HP laptops, the only reason I don’t have my Toshiba laptop anymore is because it got stolen.

Read full topic

item.title: How are those $600-700 laptops (toshiba)
item.dc:creator: Imonfire
item.description:
Deathmonkey7:

Grab one of these. You’d be better off.
https://www.newegg.com/Product/ProductList.aspx?Submit=ENE&N=2034940032+50001315+4021+1044949570+1292318470&QksAutoSuggestion=&ShowDeactivatedMark=False&Configurator=&Subcategory=32&description=&Ntk=&CFG=&SpeTabStoreType=&srchInDesc=

Asus laptops? No fuckin’ way. They’re a massive pain in the pooper to configure. IMO the best laptop there is are Lenovos. Sure they’re ugly, but they’re much cheaper, more reliable and they never die.

item.description:
Unless you plan to spend $1,000+ on a laptop, don’t expect it to play a lot of games solidly.

Although this one I bought for 600 plays CoH, which makes me happy.

Read full topic

item.title: How are those $600-700 laptops (toshiba)
item.dc:creator: Hylian7
item.description:
Well, we would have to know the specs of these laptops you are talking about. Can you post a link to one? The last $600 laptop I got from Toshiba sucked, and as for games, it could only really do GoldSrc games and lower. I wasn’t particularly a fan of that laptop in general though.

I wouldn’t suggest using a laptop as a primary gaming computer though. The ones that do games well are up in the $1000’s price range, and even the you can’t change most of the hardware like you can with a desktop. My suggestion would be to order parts and build your own desktop. Mine ran me about $800 (including operating system and monitor), which was well worth the price. If you already have a monitor you can use, then that’s a big chunk of money you are saving from the cost of building your own.

Read full topic
